story.text: (Adds official closing numbers, details)TORONTO Jan 3 (Reuters) - The Toronto Stock Exchange's main index closed down more than 200 points on Wednesday following a steep pullback in metal and oil prices, which weighed on the broader market. The Toronto Stock Exchange S&P/TSX composite index .GSPTSE closed down 222.22 points, or 1.7 percent, at 12,701.44. Eight of the TSX index's 10 main groups retreated but the hefty energy and materials groups, which include resources and gold-mining shares, were the biggest losers, down 3.9 percent and 4 percent respectively. The steep dive in energy issues was pegged on the slide in oil, which dropped more than 4 percent to settle below $59 a barrel, as unusually warm weather in the U.S. Northeast cut heating-oil demand in the world's biggest energy market. Copper prices tumbled to their lowest levels since early April, which weighed on other base metals. "The overriding reason is potential for slower growth this year weighing on commodity markets," said Fergal Smith, managing market strategist at Action Economics. "Then, of course, the energy sector has had to contend with warmer weather forecasts," he added. "These are quite big moves in percentage terms." Natural gas heavy EnCana Corp. (ECA.TO) closed down C$1.14, or 2 percent, at C$53.21, Suncor Energy Inc. (SU.TO) slid C$4.41, or 4.9 percent, to C$86.61. Zinc major Teck Cominco Ltd. (TCKb.TO) sagged C$4.53, or 5.3 percent, to C$81.40, while aluminum producer Alcan Inc. AL.TO lost C$2.38, or 4.2 percent, to close at C$53.91. ($1=$1.17 Canadian)
story.title: weak energy , metal prices drag down toronto stocks
